presentations.title: Kentik Product Portfolio
presentations.description: A structured overview of Kentik's diverse product ecosystem: The Foundation, The Core, ISP Tools, and Strategic Gaps.

sections.title: The Capability Engine
sections.subtitle: What is Kentik really?
sections.content: It is a Big Data Engine (The 'Kentik Data Engine' or KDE) that ingests trillions of records. It doesn't just 'monitor'—it records every conversation, every packet, and every routing change forever. This means we have a 'Flight Recorder' for our entire ISP business, not just a speedometer.

sections.title: Group 1: The Core Platform
sections.content: The foundational tools included in our 'Pro' License.

sections.title: Core Traffic Visibility (NPM)
sections.content:
The primary engine for visualizing traffic flow, bandwidth usage, and historical trends across the backbone.

Key Tech Specs:
• Traffic Explorer: Visualizes Top Talkers by App, ASN, and Geo.
• Capacity Planning: Automated AI forecasting of bandwidth exhaustion.
• Data Retention: 13 months of history (crucial for Year-over-Year planning).

sections.title: Infrastructure Health (NMS)
sections.content:
Replaces legacy SNMP tools by monitoring physical device health alongside traffic.

Key Tech Specs:
• Metrics: CPU, Memory, Temp, Fan Speed (SNMP).
• Streaming Telemetry: Sub-minute (seconds-level) resolution for critical backbone routers.
• Device Support: Works with Cisco, Juniper, Arista, and more.

sections.title: Synthetic Monitoring
sections.content:
Active testing robots that continuously 'ping' external services to prove network quality.

Key Tech Specs:
• Autonomous Tests: Auto-detects top traffic destinations and tests them.
• Global Agents: 200+ testing nodes worldwide.
• Page Load Tests: Checks HTTP/DNS response times for specific portals.

sections.title: AI Advisor
sections.content:
The 'Brain' of the platform that allows engineers to query network data using natural language.

Key Tech Specs:
• Natural Language Query: No SQL/coding required.
• Root Cause Analysis: AI scans for 'Unusual' patterns automatically.

sections.title: Group 2: The ISP Specialized Tools
sections.content: Specialized tools for Edge analytics and Service Provider revenue.

sections.title: Kentik Edge (Peering)
sections.content:
The 'Financial' module for managing BGP relationships and transit costs.

Key Tech Specs:
• Cost Snapshots: Dollar-per-megabit analysis of every interface.
• BGP Visualization: See AS Paths and Route Leaks in real-time.

sections.title: Service Provider Analytics (My Kentik)
sections.content:
A white-label portal that lets ISP customers see their own traffic data.

Key Tech Specs:
• White Label Portal: Your logo, your URL, their data.
• OTT Analytics: See exactly how much bandwidth Netflix/YouTube/Hulu is consuming per subscriber.

sections.title: Group 3: The Gap Products
sections.content: High-value strategic add-ons for Security and Market Intelligence.

sections.title: Kentik Protect (Advanced)
sections.content:
Enterprise-grade security to detect and mitigate attacks before they take down the network.

Key Tech Specs:
• Botnet Detection: Finds infected subscriber devices.
• Mitigation: Automates BGP Flowspec and RTBH (Remote Trigger Black Hole).

sections.title: Kentik Market Intelligence (KMI)
sections.content:
'Spyglass' into the global internet routing table to see competitor traffic and market trends.

Key Tech Specs:
• AS Rankings: Global leaderboard of ISPs by country/region.
• Market Share: See 'Eyeball' vs. 'Content' market share in any country.

sections.title: Multi-Cloud Observability
sections.content:
Visibility into public cloud networking (AWS/Azure) if your ISP offers 'Direct Connect' services.

Key Tech Specs:
• Cloud Map: Visualizes VPCs, TGWs, and Direct Connects.
• Cost Analysis: Identifies expensive cross-region cloud traffic.

sections.title: Firehose (Data Export)
sections.content:
Pushes enriched Kentik data to other internal systems.

Key Tech Specs:
• Integrations: Kafka, Splunk, New Relic, InfluxDB, S3.
• Format: JSON, NetFlow, or Influx Line Protocol.

presentations.title: Virtualization Technology Research
presentations.description: A comprehensive technical presentation covering virtualization fundamentals, hypervisors, platforms, and modern extensions.

sections.title: Virtualization Technology
sections.subtitle: Essential Research (16-Slide Overview)
sections.content: A condensed technical exploration of virtualization fundamentals, hypervisor architectures, platform comparisons, and modern extensions.

sections.title: Virtualization Fundamentals
sections.content:
Virtualization abstracts physical hardware to run multiple isolated environments on one machine.

• **Core Goal**: Maximize utilization (from 10% to 80%+) and reduce server sprawl.
• **Architecture**: A Hypervisor (VMM) translates and allocates physical resources.
• **Benefits**: Rapid provisioning, lower TCO, and simplified disaster recovery.

sections.title: CPU Virtualization
sections.content:
Hardware-assisted CPU virtualization enables near-native performance for virtual workloads.

• **Protection Rings**: x86 uses rings 0-3. Hypervisors use Ring -1 (Root Mode) to manage Guest OS in Ring 0.
• **Hardware Support**: Intel VT-x and AMD-V provide the necessary VMX instruction sets.
• **VM Exits**: Minimizes expensive transitions between Guest and Host modes.

sections.title: Memory Virtualization
sections.content:
Efficient address translation is the backbone of virtualized memory management.

• **Address Layers**: Translates Guest Virtual Address (GVA) to Guest Physical (GPA) to Host Physical (HPA).
• **Hardware Tables**: Extended/Nested Page Tables (EPT/NPT) handle this translation in hardware silicon.
• **Performance**: Significantly reduces memory access latency and hypervisor overhead.

sections.title: I/O Virtualization Techniques
sections.content:
Efficient I/O is critical for networking and storage performance.

• **Emulation**: Full simulation; maximum compatibility but highest overhead.
• **Paravirtualization (Virtio)**: Guest-aware drivers with shared memory queues; balanced performance.
• **SR-IOV**: Direct hardware function access; bypasses hypervisor for true bare-metal speeds.

sections.title: Type 1 vs Type 2 Hypervisors
sections.content:
The choice of architecture defines the performance and use-case boundaries.

• **Type 1 (Bare-Metal)**: Installs directly on hardware. Best for production, enterprise, and cloud. (ESXi, KVM, Hyper-V).
• **Type 2 (Hosted)**: Runs as an app on a host OS. Best for development, testing, and classrooms. (VirtualBox, Workstation).

items.title: VM Lifecycle
items.description: Snapshotting for rollback, cloning for scale, and Live Migration (vMotion) for zero-downtime maintenance.

items.title: CPU Scheduling
items.description: Mapping vCPUs to pCPUs via fair-share algorithms, reservations, and affinity pinning.

items.title: Resource Isolation
items.description: Hardware enforcement of memory boundaries (EPT) and device separation (IOMMU) for security.

items.title: Management Layer
items.description: Orchestration, monitoring, and automated workload balancing across clusters.

items.title: Application
items.description: Encapsulating apps (App-V, ThinApp) to run independently of the local OS.

items.title: Desktop (VDI)
items.description: Centrally hosting user desktops (Horizon, WorkSpaces) for remote access.

items.title: Network (SDN)
items.description: Decoupling routing and switching (NSX, VPC) from physical hardware.

items.title: Storage
items.description: Pooling physical disks into software-defined storage fabrics (vSAN).

items.title: Server
items.description: The foundation: partitioning physical servers into multiple VMs (ESXi, KVM).

sections.title: 1. The Partitioned Family (Hyper-V)
sections.content:
Microsoft uses a Partitioned architecture where the Root (Parent) partition manages the hardware.

• **Root Partition**: The main Windows OS; owns the physical drivers.
• **Child Partitions**: The VMs. Use Virtualization Service Clients (VSC).
• **The VMBus**: High-speed communication tunnel for child-to-parent I/O.
• **Products**: Windows Server (Hyper-V), Azure Stack HCI, Windows Pro.

sections.title: 2. The Monolithic Family (VMware)
sections.content:
VMware ESXi is a self-contained 'mini-OS' designed specifically for virtualization.

• **VMkernel**: A specialized, monolithic kernel that includes its own drivers and management stack.
• **Independence**: No 'main OS' (like Windows) runs on top. The hypervisor is the only thing on the hardware.
• **Products**: vSphere (Enterprise), Workstation (Desktop), and Fusion (Mac).

sections.title: 3. The Microkernel Family (Xen)
sections.content:
Xen uses a tiny core hypervisor that offloads hardware management to a privileged VM.

• **Dom0 (Domain 0)**: A highly-privileged VM that manages hardware drivers and other domains.
• **DomU (User Domains)**: Standard, unprivileged virtual machines.
• **Security**: Extreme isolation; this design was the original foundation for AWS EC2.

sections.title: 4. The Kernel-Based Family (KVM)
sections.content:
KVM turns the Linux kernel itself into a Type 1 hypervisor via a simple kernel module.

• **VMs as Processes**: Each VM is literally a standard Linux process (manageable via `kill` or `top`).
• **Native Efficiency**: Levages existing Linux features for memory and task scheduling.
• **Products**: Proxmox, Nutanix AHV, and the engine for AWS Nitro & Google Cloud.

sections.title: 5. The OS-Level Family (LXC)
sections.content:
Linux Containers (LXC) provide isolated sandboxes without the need for hardware virtualization.

• **The 'Cheat'**: Shares the host's kernel and uses Namespaces (isolation) and Cgroups (limits).
• **Performance**: Near-zero overhead and millisecond startup times.
• **The Limit**: Host and Guest must share the same kernel (Linux-only). Products: LXD, Incus, Proxmox.
